title: $7 million Chatham house has a private sandy beach: ‘Super desirable and rare’
author: Megan Johnson
bullets: A historic Chatham property at 150 Main Street is for sale at $6.95 million, offering a private sandy beach.
The Cape-style home, built around 1840, features seven bedrooms, 2.5 bathrooms, and 75 feet of beach frontage.
Located within Chatham's Village Historic District, the house cannot be demolished and must be restored by new owners.

title: A social media post about a traveler’s ‘masterclass in boundaries’ on a flight out of Maine goes viral
author: Kristi Palma
bullets: A social media post went viral after highlighting a woman's assertive boundary-setting on a flight out of Maine.
The post by user @digbymomma received nearly 31,000 likes, 500 comments, and 100 shares on Threads.
Commenters praised the woman's clear communication and discussed their own travel boundary experiences.

title: Is your home ready for this winter?
author: Zipporah Osei
bullets: Boston's snow total reaches 60 inches after recent blizzard, first time since 2015's 'Snowmageddon'.
Winter Home Guide offers tips on managing snow loads, ice dams, and storm preparation.
Guide provides practical advice for maintaining house safety and garden care during New England winters.

title: What Boston meteorologists are saying about the timing and impacts of Wednesday’s snow
author: Heather Alterisio
bullets: New England to see 1-3 inches of snow Wednesday morning, transitioning to rain by afternoon in southern areas.
Snow starts between 5-8 a.m., peaks from 7-11 a.m., causing slick roads and reduced visibility.
Temperatures to rise late in the week, with arctic conditions returning by late Sunday and possible snow Tuesday.

title: Some changes are in store for Kendall Square Cinema
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: Kendall Square Cinema in Cambridge will undergo extensive renovations starting in March, including larger screens and luxury seating.
Upgrades will include a giant-format screen, expanded menu, full-service bar, and new party room, completing by late summer.
Operated by Landmark Theatres, the cinema has been known for independent films and will continue to cater to diverse audiences.

title: View Boston to shutter observatory restaurants, cut 79 jobs
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: View Boston will close its observatory restaurants at the Prudential Center by April 21, 2026.
The closures will eliminate 79 jobs, including 41 full-time and 38 part-time positions.
The move follows a pivot towards hosting private events due to increasing demand in Boston.

title: Alex Cora was impressed by Ranger Suarez in limited spring training debut for Red Sox
author: Hayden Bird
bullets: Ranger Suarez made his Red Sox spring training debut, pitching 1 2/3 innings with three hits and two runs allowed.
Suarez signed a five-year, $130 million contract with Boston and is set to pitch for Venezuela in the World Baseball Classic.
Manager Alex Cora praised Suarez's calm demeanor on the mound, describing him as a competitor and 'bulldog'.

title: Local obituary: Madelyn Eitas, Rochester 11-year-old
author: Boston.com Staff
bullets: Madelyn Eitas, 11, from Rochester, passed away on February 19 while vacationing with her family.
Madelyn was known for her caring nature, love for sports, and ability to bring people together.
A Mass of Christian Burial will be held on February 28 at Saint Patrick Church in Wareham.

title: Boston couple’s wedding disrupted by blizzard — they got married anyway
author: Annie Jonas
bullets: Maddie McNamara and Drew Baker married at the Newbury Hotel after a blizzard disrupted their Boston Public Library ceremony plans.
Their wedding was held in their hotel suite with only an officiant, his fiancée, and photographer present due to the storm.
The couple braved the blizzard for memorable wedding photos on a snow-covered Newbury Street, emphasizing the day as unforgettable.

title: Dave Epstein: How long will it take for all this snow to melt?
author: David Epstein
bullets: Eastern Massachusetts, Rhode Island, and Connecticut have 1 to 3 feet of snow, among the highest levels recorded this year.
Above-freezing temperatures expected this week may initiate snow melting, but rapid melting could lead to flooding.
Historically, Boston's snow cover lasts into March; strong sun will assist melting, especially on south-facing areas.
